translated: The Sutra of the Prince's Auspicious Past, Scroll 2
Translated by Zhi Qian, an upÄsaka from Yuezhi in the Wu region
The Bodhisattva's practice of purity over many eons, up to the great compassion of Confucianism, the natural concentration of the Way, the power of forbearance
subduing demons, the ghost troops retreating and scattering, the concentrated mind as before.

Not using wisdom and deliberation, without thoughts of worry or joy, on this day in the first watch of the night, he attained the first stage of meditation and knew his past lives, the spirits and consciousnesses of countless eons, the bodies he had received in succession, beyond measure, all recognizing and knowing them.

By the second night, he attained the second stage of meditation and knew all the thoughts in the minds of sentient beings, the good and evil, blessings and misfortunes, and the destinies of their births and deaths.

By the third night, he attained the third stage of meditation, with his defilements exhausted and bonds unraveled, and knew the practices he had long cultivated in the past, the four bases of supernatural power:
the concentration of vigor, the concentration of desire, the concentration of intention, and the concentration of precepts, and attained the method of transformation.
One's desires are as one wishes, no longer needing to think. One can fly with the body, divide the body into a hundred or a thousand, up to billions and countless, and then merge it back into one.
One can penetrate the earth and pass through stone walls, appearing from one side and submerging from above, like waves in water.
One can emit water and fire from the body, walk on water without sinking,
sit and lie in the air like a bird flying,
stand and reach the heavens, and touch the sun and moon with one's hands.
If one wishes to stand level with the Brahmas,

one's eyes can see through, one's ears can hear through, and one's mind can anticipate all the thoughts of gods, humans, dragons, ghosts, insects, and all moving creatures, their bodily actions, speech, and mental desires, all of which one can see and hear.

Those with greed and lust, those without greed and lust, those with anger and hatred, those without anger and hatred, those with delusion, those without delusion, those with desire, those without desire, those with great aspirations, those without great aspirations, those with internal and external practices, those without internal and external practices, those who contemplate goodness, those who do not contemplate goodness, those with single-mindedness, those without single-mindedness, those with liberated minds, those without liberated minds - all of them he knows.

The Bodhisattva observes the five destinies of heavenly beings, humans, hell beings, animals, and hungry ghosts in the heavens, among humans, in the hells, among animals, and among hungry ghosts, as well as his parents, brothers, wives, and children from past lives, and their names and clans in the inner and outer realms, distinguishing each and every one;

The events of one lifetime, ten lifetimes, a hundred thousand, ten million, or countless lifetimes, up to the time when the world is destroyed and empty, and the time when the world is first formed and people appear, he can know ten eons, a hundred eons, up to countless millions of eons, the names of people inside and outside, their clothing, food, suffering and joy, the length of their lives, dying here and being reborn there, and their future destinies.

From the beginning of the head, the bodies that have been through, born, grown old and died, their appearance, good or bad, wise or foolish, suffering or joy, all in the three realms, he can distinguish and know.

Seeing people's souls and spirits, each following their actions, being born in the five realms, either falling into hell, or becoming animals, or becoming ghosts, or being born in the heavens, or entering human form, some being born in noble, wealthy and happy families, some being born in humble, poor and lowly families, he knows that sentient beings are sometimes obscured by the five aggregates:
First, form; second, sensation; third, conception; fourth, volition; fifth, consciousness;
All are accustomed to the five desires:
The eyes crave form, the ears crave sound, the nose craves smell, the tongue craves taste, the body craves smoothness;
Drawn by love and desire, or in regard to wealth and form, one hopes for comfort and ease. From this arise the roots of all evil, and from evil comes suffering.
One who can cut off the habit of desire and not follow lustful thoughts, even as small as a hair, and practice the Eightfold Path, will then extinguish all suffering.
It is like having no firewood and no fire. This is called the unconditioned path to transcendence.

The Bodhisattva knows for himself that he has already abandoned the roots of evil, has no more lust, anger, or delusion, has ended birth and death, has cut off the seeds and roots, has no remaining stumps, has accomplished what was to be done, and has attained wisdom.
When the morning star appeared, he suddenly had great enlightenment and attained the unsurpassed true path, becoming the supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Attaining the eighteen qualities of a Buddha, possessing the ten powers and four fearlessnesses.
As for the eighteen qualities of a Buddha, from the time of attaining Buddhahood until nirvana:
First, not losing the path; second, no empty words; third, no forgetting one's intentions; fourth,
No lack of tranquility; fifth, no various thoughts; sixth, no lack of introspection; seventh,
Intention and desire are not diminished; eighth, diligence is not diminished; ninth, concentration is not diminished,

Tenth, wisdom is not diminished; eleventh, liberation is not diminished; twelfth, the knowledge and insight of liberation are not diminished; thirteenth, all past events are known and seen; fourteenth,
All future events are known and seen; fifteenth, all present events are known and seen; sixteenth,

Transforming by observing the bodily actions of the multitude, using what was known in the beginning; seventeenth, transforming by observing the verbal actions of the multitude, using what was known in the beginning;
Eighteenth, transforming by observing the mental actions of the multitude, using what was known in the beginning.
These are the eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha.
As for the ten powers, the Buddha fully knows and sees the profound, subtle, hidden, and distant, whether it is possible or not, and clearly understands as it is, this is the first power;
The Buddha fully understands and knows the ground of actions created in the past, present, and future, and the corresponding rewards and consequences, this is the second power;
The Buddha fully discerns the various different thoughts of heavenly beings, humans, and other beings, this is the third power;
The Buddha fully knows the various languages of beings and the language of transcendence of the world, this is the fourth power;
The Buddha fully understands the immeasurable and various dispositions of the world, this is the fifth power;
The Buddha is able to manifest meditation, liberation, and concentration practices to eliminate various afflictions and disputes, this is the sixth power;
The Buddha knows the bonds of desire, knows the bonds and unbinding, and knows the appropriate practices, this is the seventh power;
The Buddha's wisdom is like the ocean, with immeasurable skillful words, and he recollects all his past lives, this is the eighth power;

The Buddha's heavenly eye is pure, seeing the death of people and beings, where their spirits are reborn, the good and evil consequences, following their actions to receive retribution, the ninth power;

The Buddha's defilements are already exhausted, no longer bound or attached, his spiritual true wisdom, knowing and seeing for himself, thoroughly understanding the practice of the Way, what can be done he is able to do, with no remaining birth and death, his wisdom is clear and discerning, this is the Buddha's tenth spiritual power.
The four kinds of fearlessness are:
The Buddha's spiritual wisdom and right enlightenment, there is nothing he does not know. Foolish and confused people say among themselves:
The Buddha does not know everything.
Even up to the Brahma assembly of sages, none can discuss the Buddha's wisdom, thus he walks alone without fear, the first fearlessness;
The Buddha's defilements are already exhausted and he knows it all. Foolish and confused people say among themselves:
The Buddha's defilements are not yet exhausted.
Even up to the Brahma assembly of sages, none can discuss the Buddha's resolve, thus he walks alone without fear, the second fearlessness;
The Buddha's sutras and precepts are recited and studied throughout the world, but the ignorant and deluded say:
The Buddha's sutras can be stopped.
Even the Brahma assembly of sages cannot discuss the Buddha's true sutras, so he walks alone without fear, the third fearlessness;
The Buddha manifests the meaning of the Way, his words are true and essential, and he can deliver one from suffering and calamity, but the ignorant and deluded say:
The Buddha cannot deliver one from suffering.
Even the Brahma assembly of sages cannot discuss the Buddha's true Way, so he travels everywhere without fear, the fourth fearlessness.
The Buddha attained concentration, omniscience, and insight. Sitting in meditation, he thought to himself:
This is truly subtle, difficult to know and understand, and very difficult to attain.
It is lofty and unsurpassed, vast and boundless;
It is deep and bottomless, profound and unfathomable;
It encompasses heaven and earth, and enters the smallest space.
In the past, when Dipankara Buddha predicted my Buddhahood, naming me Shakyamuni,
I have now attained it.
After countless eons of diligent effort, I have finally attained it.

I recall from my past lives, all that I have done with kindness, filial piety, benevolence, righteousness, propriety, respect, sincerity, impartiality, and upholding goodness. With an open mind, I studied the sages, practiced gentleness and purity, and carried out the six pÄramitÄs - giving, morality, patience, diligence, meditation, and wisdom.
I cultivated the four immeasurable minds - loving-kindness, compassion, joy, and equanimity;
Nurturing sentient beings, regarding them as my own children;
Serving the buddhas, accumulating immeasurable virtues;
Over many eons of diligent effort, without expecting any reward, I have now attained it all.
Delighted, he said to himself:
Now I realize the Buddha's supreme honor, abandoning desire, pure and free from defilements,
Able to lead all, those who follow will surely rejoice.
The reward of blessings is delightful, and my wonderful wishes are all fulfilled.
Having compassion, I have attained the supreme peace, and I will now pass into nirvana.

When the Buddha first attained enlightenment, he knew that he had eaten little and his body was light and empty. He slowly got up, entered the water to bathe, and after finishing, wanted to climb out onto the bank. The gods pressed down on a tree branch, and he was able to climb out and go to the foot of the tree.
There were five hundred blue birds that flew over and circled the Buddha three times before leaving.
There was also a long-term female patient who had just given birth and had a wish to give birth to a son. She would make a porridge of a hundred flavors and offer it to the mountain tree spirit.
Later, she gave birth to a son, and was delighted. She immediately made the porridge, filled it in a golden bowl, and poured it out. The ladle did not stick;
The woman increased her respect and went with several other women into the mountains. She saw a beautiful tree and immediately sent a maid to go and clean it up;
When the maid arrived and saw the Buddha, she did not know what kind of spirit it was. She returned and reported to the woman, saying:
'There is a spirit sitting under the tree.'
The woman told the maid to place the porridge of a hundred flavors on her head, kneel for a long time, and offer the food along with the golden bowl.

'You are able to have good intentions, and will surely attain blessings and see the truth in this very life.'

The many women bowed from afar and withdrew. The Buddha then finished eating the porridge. He thought of the first three Buddhas when they first attained the Way, they all had offerings of food of a hundred flavors and golden bowls like this vessel, which are now all in the possession of the Manjushri Dragon.
The Buddha then threw the bowl into the water, and it naturally flowed upstream for seven miles, falling on top of the previous three bowls. The four vessels stacked together, resembling one.
The Dragon King was delighted, knowing that there was a Buddha again.
The Buddha was in samÄdhi for seven days, unmoving and unshakable.
The tree spirit thought:
'The Buddha has newly attained the Way and has been sitting for seven days. No one has offered him food yet. I shall seek people to offer food to the Buddha.'
At that time, there were just five hundred merchants passing by one side of the mountain. The carts and oxen all stumbled and would not move forward.

There were two great men, one named Tiwei and the other named Boli. They were frightened and returned with the group to the tree spirit to request blessings. The spirit manifested a radiant image and said:
Now there is a Buddha in this world, by the Nairajnana River in the borderlands of Urumunda. No one has yet offered him food.
You are fortunate to be able to have good intentions first, and will surely obtain great blessings.
The merchants heard the Buddha's name and all rejoiced, saying:
The Buddha must be the most revered, respected by the celestial spirits, not an ordinary person.
They mixed flour and honey, went together to the tree, bowed, and offered it to the Buddha.
The Buddha thought, 'In the past, all Buddhas accepted people's offerings using alms bowls. It is not appropriate to receive food with one's hands like other monks.'
At that time, the Four Heavenly Kings immediately knew that the Buddha would need alms bowls. In the time it takes for a person to bend and extend their arm, they all went to Mount Anavatapta;
As they wished, four alms bowls naturally emerged from the stone, fragrant, clean, and spotless.
The Four Heavenly Kings each took a bowl and returned to offer it to the Buddha, saying:
We pray that you take pity on the merchants and allow them to obtain great blessings.
There are iron bowls later that the disciples will use for meals.

The Buddha thought that accepting only one bowl would not please the other three, so he accepted all four bowls, placed them one on top of the other in his left hand, pressed them down with his right hand, and fused them into one bowl, with the edges of the four bowls still visible.
The Buddha accepted the honey mixture and told the merchants:
You should take refuge in the Buddha, take refuge in the Dharma, and there will be a community of monks. You should take refuge in them in advance.
They immediately followed his instructions and each took refuge three times.
The Buddha rose to another place, finished his meal, and made a vow for the merchants, saying:
The alms you have given now are meant to nourish the eater and provide them with strength.

It should cause the donor's family to have their wishes fulfilled in life after life, to obtain good looks, strength, respect, and joy, to be peaceful and well, without illness, and to have a long life.
Evil and malicious ghosts will not be able to disturb or approach them;
Because they have wholesome thoughts and establish firm roots of virtue,
All the good ghosts and spirits will always protect them;
They will be shown the stages of the path and attain favorable circumstances;
They will not encounter difficulties or hardships;
Those who have right views and with faith, joy, and respect
Give to those of moral virtue with purity and without regret,
Their blessings and virtues will greatly increase, and whatever they pursue will be excellent, with auspiciousness and no lack of benefit.
The sun, moon, five planets, twenty-eight lunar mansions, celestial spirits, and ghost kings will always follow and assist them;

You will now experience auspiciousness, and by planting blessings you will obtain blessings, by practicing the Way you will attain the Way. By first seeing the Buddha and wholeheartedly serving him, you will thereby attain the foremost blessings.
In this very life you will obtain protection, quickly understand and see the truth, be wealthy, happy, and long-lived, and attain nirvana on your own.
At that time, the gruel was cold, and a wind arose in the Buddha's belly. Åšakra immediately knew and went to the border of JambudvÄ«pa, took a medicinal fruit called Ämalaka, and said to the Buddha:

He then went to the side of the water of the blind dragon Wenlin Wuti, sat in concentration for seven days, without panting or breathing;
The light illuminated the water, the dragon's eyes opened, and he recognized himself as before. Seeing the light of the three Buddhas, his eyes could immediately see.
The dragon king was delighted, bathed in famous incense, sandalwood, and olibanum, and came out of the water;
Seeing the Buddha's majestic appearance and radiance like a tree in bloom, he circumambulated the Buddha seven times, his body forty li away from the Buddha's retinue;
The dragon had seven heads, covering the Buddha above;
Wishing to shield him from mosquitoes, flies, cold, and heat, it rained for seven days, the dragon single-mindedly, neither hungry nor thirsty.
After seven days of rain, the Buddha awoke. The dragon transformed into a young man, put on fine clothes, bowed to the Buddha, and asked:
Did the Buddha not feel cold, hot, or bothered by mosquitoes and flies?
The Buddha then replied:
Having long been in seclusion, contemplating the Way, its blessings are delightful;
The sutras I wished to hear in the past, now that I have fully understood them, it is delightful;
Not being bothered by them, able to bring peace to sentient beings, it is delightful;
Crossing the world, the three poisons extinguished, attaining the Buddha's nirvana, it is delightful;
Being born in the world and seeing the Buddha, hearing and receiving the sutras and Dharma, it is delightful;
To be able to meet with pratyekabuddhas and true people is also joyful;
Not associating with fools, being able to leave bad people is joyful;
Having wisdom to distinguish true from false, knowing and believing in the right path is joyful.
The Buddha told the dragon king:
You should take refuge in the Buddha, take refuge in the Dharma, and take refuge in the Sangha.
He immediately accepted the Three Refuges.
Among the animals, this dragon was the first to see the Buddha.
The Buddha used his spiritual powers to move his seat to a stone chamber, and thought to himself about his original vow to deliver sentient beings.
He contemplated:
The basis of birth and death arises from the Dharma of the twelve links of dependent origination. Because the Dharma arises, there is birth and death;
If the Dharma ceases, birth and death will come to an end.
Because of this, one attains this. If one does not do this, this will cease.

The minds of all sentient beings are the spiritual essence. They are dark and obscure, vague and formless. They give rise to consciousness and ideas on their own, and follow their actions to receive bodies;
The body has no permanent master, and the spirit has no permanent form. The spirit and mind transform and change, agitated and turbid, difficult to purify;
It is born and extinguished by itself, never resting;
One thought goes, one thought comes;
Like bubbles in water, one disappears and another arises;
Up to the three realms of desire, form, and formlessness, the nine abodes of the spirit are all bound to consciousness, unable to escape suffering;
Unconsciously unaware, it is called ignorance, not knowing the essential path.
The Way is supremely subtle, empty and tranquil, without thought, and cannot be known by ordinary worldly thoughts.
The ninety-six kinds of worldly arts and techniques, each believing in what they practice, who knows their delusions?
They all enjoy life, seek comfort, crave desires, relish flavors, and delight in sounds and colors, thus they cannot enjoy the Buddha's Way.
The Buddha's Way is pure, empty, and nothing exists;
Ordinary people think that the myriad things of the body cannot be permanently obtained, if they are told, the world is all suffering;
Who can believe in emptiness and nothingness?
I am only withered, suffering, and self-centered.
' With the intention to remain silent and not teach the Dharma to the world, he immediately entered meditative concentration.
The Buddha emitted light from his eyebrows, illuminating the seven heavens above.
Brahma Heaven knew that the Buddha was about to attain nirvana and felt sad, thinking:

The three realms are all in long decline, and in the end they do not know the Dharma of transcending the world. After death, they will fall back into the three evil paths. When will they be liberated?

It has been a long time since the Buddha appeared in the world, and it is difficult to see the Buddha, like the udumbara flower. Now I should request on behalf of the gods and humans, begging the Buddha to stop teaching the sutra.
He then spoke to Indra, and the heavenly musicians Pancha brought their instruments and descended to the Stone Room.
The Buddha was just about to awaken from meditative concentration when Pancha plucked the zither and sang.
The lyrics said:
Listen to me sing about the Ten Powers, abandoning hindrances, peacefully concentrated in meditation;
The light shines through and illuminates the seven heavens, and the fragrance of virtue surpasses sandalwood.
The divine and wondrous one from above came, praising and looking up, wanting to see the Honored One;
Brahma and Shakra brought respectful intentions, bowing their heads, wanting to receive the teachings.
The Buddha's original practices and vows, diligently striving for a hundred kalpas;
Great giving with the four immeasurable minds, the ten directions receiving vast kindness.
Upholding precepts, pure and without defilement, compassionately protecting sentient beings;
Resolutely entering the wisdom of meditation, with great compassion expounding the sutras for liberation.
Accumulating austerities countless times, merits and virtues accomplished now;
The power of precepts, patience, concentration, and wisdom, shaking the earth and capturing Mara.
Virtues covering the heavens and earth, spiritual wisdom surpassing the sages;
Unique and incomparable in appearance and virtue, the eight sounds reverberating in the ten directions.
Aspiration lofty like Mount Sumeru, the sublime and wondrous cannot be discussed;
Forever free from lust, anger, and delusion, no more suffering of old age and death.
Only pity to awaken from concentration, having compassion for the devas and humans;
To open the treasure trove of the Dharma, and spread the precious nectar of wisdom.
Allowing them to be liberated from worry and fear, and those in danger to find peace;
Those who are confused will see the right path, and those with wrong views will see the true words.
All wish to happily listen and accept without weariness;
You should open the Dharma of immortality, and bestow transformation for eternity.
The Buddha's mind knew all this, and he then awoke from his concentration.
Brahma Heaven addressed the Buddha, saying:
For a long time, I have only now seen the Buddha again.
The gods rejoice and wish to hear the Buddha's Dharma. You should speak the sutras for the world, and do not enter parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Sentient beings are foolish and dark, lacking the eye of wisdom. Merely bestow compassionate guidance, allowing them to attain liberation.
Among the gods and humans, there are many virtuous and good people who are fond of the Way and easily understand it. There are also those who are diligent and able to accept the precepts and Dharma.
Those who fear the three evil paths of hell, wish to open the Dharma treasury and manifest the sweet dew. Those who accept it will certainly be many.
When there is no Buddha in the world, I see other practitioners who possess the three poisons and create scriptures according to their own intentions.
People still study their inauthentic teachings, let alone the pure teachings of the Buddha free from desire, anger, and ignorance?
I wish the Buddha would speak the Dharma and let sentient beings hear the authentic path.'
The Buddha said:
'Excellent, excellent!
Brahma Heaven!
You wish to widely bestow peace and security, save the world, comfort and benefit, and bring happiness and liberation.

I contemplate the world, where those who are greedy, lustful, and fall into the suffering of birth and death are few who can awaken to the original arising from the twelve links of dependent origination: ignorance conditions ignorance, action conditions action, consciousness conditions consciousness, name-and-form conditions name-and-form, the six sense bases condition the six sense bases, contact conditions contact, feeling conditions feeling, craving conditions craving, clinging conditions clinging, existence conditions existence, birth conditions birth, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair.
The great affliction is that the spirit, following love, undergoes birth and death.

Those who wish to attain the Way should sever greed and love, eliminate emotional desires, be unconditioned and unarisen, and then ignorance will cease. When ignorance ceases, then karmic formations cease. When karmic formations cease, then consciousness ceases. When consciousness ceases, then name-and-form cease. When name-and-form cease, then the six sense bases cease. When the six sense bases cease, then contact ceases. When contact ceases, then feeling ceases. When feeling ceases, then craving ceases. When craving ceases, then grasping ceases. When grasping ceases, then becoming ceases. When becoming ceases, then birth ceases. When birth ceases, then old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, dejection, and distress all end;
this is called attaining the Way.
Only the Buddha awakens to this, which is subtle and difficult to understand.
This purity without deluded thoughts cannot be known by the minds of ordinary beings in the world.

The ninety-six kinds of arts and techniques in the world each have their own practices, some serve Heaven, Earth, the sun, moon, and the five planets, some serve water, fire, ghosts, spirits, and dragons, all seeking happiness and comfort, greedy for desires and flavors, fond of sounds and colors, thus they cannot enjoy the Buddha's path, do not hear the Buddha's scriptures, and do not know the essential Dharma.

Ordinary people's minds are different, they consider the body and myriad things to be eternally existent, if I were to tell them that what the eyes see, myriad things are impermanent, having a body is suffering, the body is not the body, empty and nothing, relatives and family members are all not people,
Straight words seem contrary, who can believe them?
I would rather enter nirvana than suffer in vain, thus I wish not to speak.
Brahma Heaven said again:
For countless eons, people have been in the world, transmigrating through birth and death, only the Buddha's scriptures are difficult to hear,
Those who were able to be liberated to the utmost while the Buddha was in the world, now have attained their wishes, rare among humans,
The supreme honor is incomparable to the Buddha, therefore I bow my head in reverence.
The world is bound and attached for a long time in darkness, now the Ten Powers have arisen, the spiritual wisdom is immeasurable,
They will open the Dharma treasury and bestow the light of wisdom, illuminating the devas and humans, enabling them to attain understanding,
The Buddha is able to liberate all, therefore I vow to take refuge.
From the beginning, you vowed to be for the suffering people, diligently accumulating virtue, your practice and vows are already accomplished,
Ignorance, old age, and death are long-lasting afflictions, lamentable, you will bestow the Dharma medicine to save all the sick and pained,
There is none more compassionate than the Buddha, therefore I bow my head in request.
The Buddha has already accepted Brahma Heaven's thought:
Who can be liberated first?

They then returned the way they came. The five people saw the Buddha and said to each other:
Be careful not to rise when this person comes.
